Utterance: Welcome back! How have you been since our last session?
Hi, Ellie! I’ve been doing alright. I actually tried painting like we talked about.
That’s wonderful! How was the experience for you?
It was really nice. I felt relaxed, and it was great to just focus on something creative.
I’m so glad to hear that! Did you find it helped with your feelings of being in "one note land"?
Yes, it definitely brightened my mood a bit. I think I’ll keep it up.
That’s fantastic! Regular creativity can really help with emotional expression. Did you have the chance to socialize since our last talk?
Yes, I went to a small gathering and tried to introduce myself to someone new.
How did that go?
It was a bit awkward at first, but I managed to talk to someone for a little while. I felt proud of myself.
That’s a huge accomplishment! It’s great that you stepped out of your comfort zone. How did it feel afterward?
It felt good, but I was also drained afterward, which I guess is normal for me now.
That’s completely understandable. Socializing can take a lot of energy, especially if it’s not something you’re used to. How did you cope with that drain?
I just took some time to myself afterward. I watched some reality TV to unwind.
That sounds like a healthy way to recharge. It’s important to give yourself that space. Speaking of your dad, did you have the opportunity to talk with him about your feelings?
I did! I approached him like we practiced, and he was surprisingly receptive.
That’s great news! What did he say?
He listened, and while he didn’t completely agree, he said he would try to understand my perspective more.
That’s a positive step! It shows that he values your feelings. How did that make you feel?
It made me feel relieved. I didn’t expect him to be so open.
That’s a wonderful outcome. It sounds like you’re making progress in your communication with him. Is there anything else you’d like to address today?
I think I still struggle with feeling like I don’t belong here in L.A. Sometimes I miss home more than I thought I would.
That’s a valid feeling, especially since you mentioned how close-knit your family is. Have you thought about ways to maintain that connection while you’re here?
I’ve been trying to call my family more often, but it’s still hard. I feel like I’m missing out on things.
It’s tough to balance those feelings. Perhaps you could plan a visit back home or even organize a family video call to feel more connected?
I could definitely try to set up a video call. That might help.
That sounds like a good plan! Making those connections can help ease that sense of longing. Have you noticed any changes in your anxiety since we began working together?
I think I’m managing it a bit better. I still have moments, but I feel more equipped to deal with them.
That’s a great sign of progress! What strategies do you think have been most helpful for you?
I think the breathing exercises and focusing on creativity have made a difference. They help me stay grounded.
I’m glad to hear that! Would you like to explore any new techniques or coping strategies today?
Maybe we could look into mindfulness? I’ve heard it can be helpful.
Absolutely! Mindfulness can be a powerful tool. Would you like to try a short mindfulness exercise together now?
Yes, I’d like that.
Let’s take a moment to find a comfortable position. Close your eyes if that feels okay. Focus on your breath. Inhale deeply… hold… and exhale slowly. Just notice how your body feels in this moment.
<breathes deeply> It feels calming.
Good. As you breathe, try to let go of any thoughts that come to mind. Acknowledge them, then let them drift away like clouds in the sky.
I like this. It feels freeing.
That’s wonderful! Mindfulness can help you stay present and reduce anxiety. Would you be willing to practice this a few times a week?
Yes, I think I can commit to that.
Great! Let’s check in about your experience with mindfulness in our next session. Is there anything else you’d like to cover today?
I think that’s it for now. I feel good about what we discussed.
I’m glad to hear that! Remember to keep practicing those new strategies, and I look forward to our next session. Take care!
Thank you, Ellie! See you next time!
Bye!
